data.event: The area was first explored by Bruni D'Entrecasteaux in 1792 and was settled in the early 19th century by timber cutters, whalers and sealers.
It was just north of Kettering in Oyster Cove that the last Tasmanian Aboriginal settlement was established in 1847.

event.title: had been rounded up some years

data.event: Aborigines from all over Van Diemen's Land had been rounded up some years earlier and isolated on Flinders Island.
In 1847 the remnants, now only 44 people, were taken to a reserve at Oyster Cove.
By 1855 there were only 16 people left and by 1869 only Truganini remained.
By 1855 there were only 16 people left and by 1869 only Truganini remained.
She died in 1876 but it was not until 1976 that her ashes were thrown to the winds on the D'Entrecasteaux Channel.
She died in 1876 but it was not until 1976 that her ashes were thrown to the winds on the D'Entrecasteaux Channel.
Little Oyster Cove Post Office opened on 19 October 1868 and was renamed Kettering in 1892.
